front: What PHQ-9 score indicates clinical depression needing treatment?
back:
≥10 (Moderate depression)
• 0-4: Minimal
• 5-9: Mild
• 10-14: Moderate
• 15-19: Moderately Severe
• 20-27: Severe

front: What MMSE score indicates cognitive impairment?
back:
<24
• 25-30: Normal
• 21-24: Mild impairment
• 10-20: Moderate impairment
• 0-9: Severe impairment

front: At what CIWA score do you start benzodiazepines?
back:
>8
• 0-9: Normal
• 10-15: Mild → Standing benzos
• 16-20: Moderate → Standing benzos
• 21+: Severe → Standing benzos

front: At what COWS score do you start buprenorphine?
back:
>7 (especially >13 for standing medication)
• 0-4: None
• 5-12: Mild → PRN
• 13-24: Moderate → Standing med
• 25-35: Moderate-Severe
• 36+: Severe

front: What GAD-7 score indicates clinical anxiety?
back:
≥10
• 0-4: Minimal
• 5-9: Mild
• 10-14: Moderate
• 15-21: Severe

front: What HAM-D score indicates severe depression?
back:
≥19
• 0-7: Normal
• 8-13: Mild
• 14-18: Moderate
• 19+: Severe

front: What BECK score indicates moderate depression?
back:
20-28
• 0-13: Minimal
• 14-19: Mild
• 20-28: Moderate
• 29-63: Severe

front: What is the therapeutic lithium level for maintenance?
back:
0.6-1.2 mEq/L
• Acute mania: 0.8-1.2
• Maintenance: 0.6-1.0
• Toxicity: >1.5

front: When do you draw lithium levels?
back: 12 hours after last dose (trough level)

front: Which medications can DOUBLE lithium levels?
back:
NSAIDs and ACE inhibitors
• Avoid ibuprofen, naproxen
• Use acetaminophen instead

front: What is the #1 cause of lithium toxicity?
back:
DEHYDRATION
• Educate patients to stay hydrated!

front: What is the most common endocrine side effect of lithium?
back:
HYPOTHYROIDISM
• Monitor TSH every 6-12 months
• Do NOT stop lithium - add levothyroxine

front: What is the most common renal side effect of lithium?
back:
Polyuria and polydipsia (excessive urination/thirst)
• Can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

front: What is the risk of lithium in pregnancy?
back:
Ebstein's Anomaly (cardiac defect - tricuspid valve)
• Pregnancy Category D
• Always get pregnancy test first!

front: What genetic test is required before starting Tegretol in Asians?
back: HLA-B*1502 (Stevens-Johnson Syndrome risk)

front: Is carbamazepine an inducer or inhibitor?
back:
INDUCER (hepatic enzyme)
• Lowers levels of other drugs
• Including oral contraceptives!

front: What is the biggest pregnancy risk with Depakote?
back:
Spina bifida (neural tube defects)
• 1-2% risk (10-20x normal)
• Always get pregnancy test!
• Give folic acid 5 mg/day

front: What is the loading dose of Depakote for acute mania?
back: 20 mg/kg

front: Which is better for rapid cycling bipolar?
back: Depakote (more effective than lithium for rapid cycling and mixed episodes)

front: Why must you titrate Lamictal slowly?
back:
Stevens-Johnson Syndrome risk
• Start 25 mg x 2 weeks → 50 mg x 2 weeks → 100 mg
• Even SLOWER if on valproate (inhibitor)

front: At what ANC level do you INTERRUPT clozapine?
back:
ANC 1000-1499
• ≥1500: Continue
• 1000-1499: Interrupt, monitor daily
• 500-999: STOP, do not rechallenge
• <500: STOP PERMANENTLY

front: What happens to clozapine levels if patient QUITS smoking?
back:
Levels DOUBLE (toxicity risk!)
• Smoking is CYP1A2 inducer
• Must reduce dose when quitting

front: Why do you need baseline ECG before Geodon?
back:
QTc prolongation risk → Torsades de Pointes
• Do NOT use if QTc >500 msec

front: Which antipsychotic has HIGHEST metabolic side effects?
back:
Clozapine (#1), then Olanzapine (#2)
• "COZY" = Clozapine and Olanzapine are cozy with weight gain!

front: Which antipsychotic has LOWEST metabolic risk?
back: Ziprasidone or Lurasidone

front: Which antipsychotics cause MORE EPS?
back:
TYPICAL (first-generation)
• Haldol, Thorazine, Fluphenazine
• Atypicals have LOWER EPS, HIGHER metabolic effects

front: How do you distinguish NMS from Serotonin Syndrome?
back:
• NMS: Lead pipe rigidity, HYPOreflexia
• SS: Hyperreflexia, myoclonus
• NMS: Slow onset (days-weeks)
• SS: Rapid onset (hours)

front: What are the cardinal signs of NMS?
back:
FEVER
• **F**ever
• **E**ncephalopathy (altered mental status)
• **V**ital sign instability
• **E**levated enzymes (CPK, WBC)
• **R**igidity (lead pipe)

front: What is the mechanism of SSRIs?
back:
Inhibit serotonin reuptake
• Examples: Prozac, Zoloft, Paxil, Lexapro, Celexa

front: What is the mechanism of Wellbutrin?
back:
NDRI (Norepinephrine-Dopamine Reuptake Inhibitor)
• No sexual side effects
• Helps with smoking cessation

front: What is the major contraindication for Wellbutrin?
back:
Eating disorders (bulimia, anorexia)
• Lowers seizure threshold
• Electrolyte abnormalities increase seizure risk

front: What is the ONLY FDA-approved medication for bulimia?
back: Prozac (fluoxetine) 60 mg/day

front: What antidepressant is best for patient who wants to quit smoking?
back:
Wellbutrin (Bupropion/Zyban)
• FDA-approved for both

front: What antidepressant is best for patient with depression and insomnia?
back:
Mirtazapine (Remeron) or Trazodone
• Sedating properties

front: What antidepressant treats both depression and neuropathic pain?
back:
Duloxetine (Cymbalta) - SNRI
• FDA-approved for diabetic neuropathy

front: Is SSRI Discontinuation Syndrome the same as Serotonin Syndrome?
back:
NO!
• Discontinuation = LACK of serotonin (flu-like, brain zaps)
• Serotonin Syndrome = EXCESS serotonin (hyperreflexia, agitation)

front: What are the symptoms of SSRI Discontinuation Syndrome?
back:
• Flu-like symptoms
• Brain zaps (paresthesias)
• Dizziness, vertigo
• Irritability, crying
• Insomnia

front: Name the opioid that causes serotonin syndrome
back:
Meperidine (Demerol)
• NEVER combine with MAOIs!
• Also: SSRIs, TCAs, Tramadol, Trazodone, Buspirone, Cocaine, MDMA

front: What medication treats MAOI hypertensive crisis?
back:
Phentolamine (alpha-blocker)
• Caused by tyramine-rich foods or sympathomimetics

front: At what age should head lag disappear?
back:
4 months
• Red flag if persists beyond 4 months

front: When does the Moro reflex disappear?
back: 4-6 months

front: When does the Babinski reflex disappear?
back:
12-24 months
• Pathological if persists after 24 months

front: What is Erikson's stage for infancy?
back: Trust vs. Mistrust

front: What is Erikson's stage for ages 1-3?
back: Autonomy vs. Shame and Doubt

front: What is Erikson's stage for adolescence?
back: Identity vs. Role Confusion

front: What is Erikson's stage for middle adulthood?
back: Generativity vs. Stagnation

front: What is Piaget's stage for ages 2-7?
back: Preoperational

front: What is Piaget's stage for ages 7-11?
back: Concrete Operational

front: When does object permanence develop?
back: 8-12 months

front: What is the minimum duration for Major Depressive Disorder?
back: 2 weeks

front: What is the minimum duration for Generalized Anxiety Disorder?
back: 6 months

front: What is the minimum duration for PTSD?
back: 1 month (after trauma)

front: Within what timeframe must Adjustment Disorder symptoms begin?
back: Within 3 months of stressor

front: What is the minimum duration for schizophrenia diagnosis?
back: 6 months (including prodrome)

front: What is the duration for Brief Psychotic Disorder?
back: <1 month

front: What is the duration for Schizophreniform Disorder?
back: 1-6 months

front: What are the Cluster A personality disorders?
back:
• Paranoid
• Schizoid
• Schizotypal
• (Odd, eccentric, suspicious)

front: What are the Cluster B personality disorders?
back:
• Antisocial
• Borderline
• Histrionic
• Narcissistic
• (Dramatic, emotional, impulsive)

front: What are the Cluster C personality disorders?
back:
• Avoidant
• Dependent
• Obsessive-Compulsive PD
• (Anxious, fearful)

front: What should you ALWAYS ask about with Borderline PD?
back:
Childhood sexual abuse
• High correlation with trauma

front: What is the gold standard treatment for Borderline PD?
back: DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy)

front: What substance use disorder is most common with Antisocial PD?
back: Alcohol (ETOH) abuse

front: What does EMDR stand for?
back:
Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing
• Used for PTSD

front: What is the first-line therapy for OCD?
back: CBT with Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP)

front: What is the first-line medication for pediatric OCD?
back:
Zoloft (Sertraline) - FDA-approved age 6+
• Also: Prozac (age 7+), Luvox (age 8+)

front: What does OARS stand for in Motivational Interviewing?
back:
• **O**pen-ended questions
• **A**ffirmations
• **R**eflective listening
• **S**ummaries

front: What is the difference between transference and countertransference?
back:
• **Transference:** Patient's feelings toward therapist
• **Countertransference:** Therapist's feelings toward patient

front: What is the "identified patient" in family therapy?
back:
The family member presenting with symptoms (symptom bearer)
• Dysfunction is in the SYSTEM, not just the individual

front: What are the primary functions of the frontal lobe?
back:
• Executive function
• Motor control
• Speech production (Broca's area)
• Personality, impulse control

front: What are the primary functions of the temporal lobe?
back:
• Hearing
• Memory (hippocampus)
• Language comprehension (Wernicke's area)
• Emotion (amygdala)

front: What are the primary functions of the parietal lobe?
back:
• Sensory processing
• Spatial awareness
• Proprioception

front: What are the primary functions of the occipital lobe?
back: Vision (visual processing)

front: What is the primary function of the amygdala?
back: Emotional center (fear, anxiety, aggression)

front: What is the primary function of the hippocampus?
back: Memory formation and consolidation

front: What is the primary function of the prefrontal cortex?
back: Executive function (planning, decision-making, impulse control)

front: What neurotransmitter is deficient in Parkinson's disease?
back: Dopamine

front: What neurotransmitter is deficient in Alzheimer's disease?
back: Acetylcholine

front: What is the Tarasoff duty to warn?
back: If patient makes credible threat against identifiable person, you MUST:

front: What is the difference between competence and capacity?
back:
• **Competence:** Legal determination by court
• **Capacity:** Clinical assessment by provider

front: What is Habeas Corpus?
back:
Right to hearing/review of involuntary commitment
• "Produce the body"

front: What are the criteria for involuntary commitment?
back:
Mental illness AND:
• Danger to self OR
• Danger to others OR
• Gravely disabled (cannot meet basic needs)

front: What state must you be licensed in for telepsychiatry?
back: The state where the PATIENT is located

front: What is the highest level of evidence for clinical practice?
back: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses of RCTs

front: Which demographic has the HIGHEST suicide completion rate?
back: White males in midlife (age 40-60)

front: When is the highest risk period for suicide after psychiatric hospitalization?
back: First week, especially first 24-48 hours

front: What is the medication principle for elderly patients?
back:
"Start low, go slow"
• More sensitive to side effects

front: Which mood stabilizer has the highest teratogenic risk?
back: Depakote (Valproic Acid) → Spina bifida

front: Which mood stabilizer is safest in pregnancy?
back: Lamictal (Lamotrigine)

front: What is the pregnancy risk with lithium?
back:
Ebstein's Anomaly (cardiac defect)
• ALWAYS get pregnancy test before starting!

front: When should you get ECG before starting ADHD stimulants?
back:
Family history of:
• Sudden cardiac death
• Cardiomyopathy
• Long QT syndrome
• Arrhythmias

front: What is the first-line medication for pediatric ADHD?
back: Stimulants (Methylphenidate or Amphetamine)

front: What is the first-line medication for pediatric depression?
back:
SSRIs (Prozac or Lexapro)
• Prozac FDA-approved age 8+
• Lexapro FDA-approved age 12+

front: What is cultural humility?
back:
Lifelong process of:
• Self-reflection
• Recognizing power imbalances
• Learning FROM patients about THEIR culture

front: What is the FIRST thing you do when patient discloses rape?
back:
Reassure her of SAFETY
• Then: Medical care, evidence preservation, support

front: What is the #1 priority in crisis intervention?
back:
SAFETY assessment
• Danger to self/others

front: What is the difference between suicidal ideation and intent?
back:
• **Ideation:** Thoughts of suicide
• **Intent:** Plan and determination to act

front: When are restraints/seclusion appropriate?
back:
ONLY when:
• Imminent danger to self/others AND
• Less restrictive interventions have failed

front: How often must you check a patient in restraints?
back:
Q15 minutes
• Offer food/water/bathroom
• Remove ASAP

front: What labs should you check before diagnosing depression?
back:
• TSH
• CBC
• CMP
• Vitamin D
• B12

front: What are the classic symptoms of hypothyroidism? (Remember: Everything slows down)
back:
• Weight gain
• Cold intolerance
• Thick, dry skin
• Heavy periods
• Depression
• Bradycardia
• Constipation

front: High TSH indicates what?
back:
HYPOTHYROIDISM (low thyroid function)
• Remember: TSH and T4 are INVERSE

front: What is harm reduction?
back:
Practical strategies to reduce negative consequences WITHOUT requiring abstinence
• Examples: Needle exchange, naloxone distribution

front: What is medication-assisted treatment (MAT) for opioid use?
back: Buprenorphine or Methadone + Counseling

front: What is required to perform biofeedback?
back: CERTIFICATION (BCIA)

front: How many criteria are needed for metabolic syndrome diagnosis?
back: 3 out of 5:

front: Can NPs recommend medical marijuana?
back:
VARIES BY STATE - Know your state laws
• Federal law: Still Schedule I

front: Which antipsychotics have highest metabolic risk?
back: COZY = **C**lozapine and **O**lan**ZY**apine

front: What does TIRED stand for in hypothyroidism?
back:
• **T**hick skin, hair loss
• **I**rregular/heavy periods
• **R**eflex delay
• **E**dema (myxedema)
• **D**epression, weight gain

front: What does FEVER stand for in NMS?
back:
• **F**ever
• **E**ncephalopathy
• **V**ital sign instability
• **E**levated enzymes
• **R**igidity

front: Why think of PACU patients for serotonin syndrome?
back:
Post-op patients get:
• Meperidine (Demerol) for pain
• Ondansetron (Zofran) for nausea
• May already be on SSRIs
